text: Please introduce yourself.

I'm Chris McKenna,

for Private Networks for AWS.
Thanks for your time.

Kurt, enterprises are increasingly learning

of the benefits
of Shared Spectrum operation.

Spectrum operation such as CBRS is well suited
and benefits 4G, 5G, private wireless network deployments?
Sure. Thanks, Sepehr.

So, you know, private networks
really put the power of connectivity
into the hands of the enterprise.

And Shared Spectrum underpins
that capability by creating a very open

ecosystem model that allows for customers,
you know, our partners
to easily deploy a

private 5G network
to meet the needs of their enterprise.

We are an ISV partner for AWS,
and what that means is we help customers

with the design, deployment,
and operation of those networks
and through that capability,
we run all that on AWS infrastructure.

As I said, unlocking this, you know,
really unique connectivity option

for enterprises to improve the quality
of their connectivity,
you know, really move the cost into their full control

and Shared Spectrum
being the key enabler for that.
That's great.

Thanks, Kurt And Chris, can you share

from AWS on integrated
private wireless in offering,

and how do you see this offering evolve
into a fully hosted storefront?
Yeah, so last week we made an announcement

of the AWS integrated
private wireless program.
This is a program

specifically designed to help partners
do exactly what Kurt was describing there,

which is to build, operate and scale
private wireless.

And we do that
by bringing our edge ecosystem into play.

We do that by pre-integrating ISV’s
for connectivity solutions.
We do that by then connecting that to our

cloud services,
of which there are over 200 today.
And lastly, we bring our
over the top application, ISV’s,

to sort of complete
the picture as a full end to end solution.

And we then work with our partners,
such as Federated Wireless, to

build that together
into a managed services offering

and then offer that
through a new storefront that we've

that we've deployed
as part of this program.
So that is, we're calling that the Integrated Private Wireless Portal.
Bit of a mouthful.

And on there you'll
see, soon, Federated Wireless Solutions.

That's awesome,
that's great. Thanks.
Thanks, Chris.

and control, as you and I like,
you know, and broadly,

your views of how observability

and control enables private wireless

its application
to private wireless networks?
So I think broadly,
telcos as well as any network provider

and also the complexity that Chris
was referring to in private networks,

the challenges
I think are threefold.
One, high cardinality data.

So you have observability metrics
from all of these different devices
and end users, particularly with smart devices
these days, emitting so many metrics.

And the second one
is to build out this complex

private 5G,
you have, it’s typically multi-vendor

and multi-vendors come with their own
monitoring solutions, which makes it more

challenging
and not a single pane of glass.

The third, last but not least, is
you have operational
metrics like IT data

and you also have network data
and each of them have their own tools.

So you don't have a single view
and there's no correlation
between across those.

So we use and we're partnering
with Federated, as you know,
with cloud, integrating CloudWatch from the ground up,
so you have observability at scale.
One of the tidbits I like telling people,
CloudWatch emits nine quadrillion metric events every month.
So nine quadrillion,

just to think of it, it's like dollar
bill stack, not end to end,

but on top of each other
6.6 times to the sun and back.
So that's the scale at which we operate.
And so
integrating those solutions at the upfront

I think is super critical
for private 5G as well.
That's great.

That is amazing actually,
in terms of the number of transactions,
that Amazon CloudWatch actually supports.
Chris and Kurt like to hear from you guys,
what do you hear from the customers

that actually have deployed
private wireless networks?
What are the stories? The good, bad, and ugly, please?
Yeah, I think I mean, one trend
that we're seeing before I give a few
interesting elements.

One trend that we're seeing
is that the conversations

we're having with customers are no longer
just about networks.
They're about solving a business problem.

So that tends to be very focused
on specific industries.
So it's,

you know, one solution for one industry
may not be valid for another industry.
So we're seeing a very industry verticalized approach
start to emerge.

But in all those conversations,
there are three consistent points
that we keep hearing.

Enterprises
don't like high upfront CapEx costs.
They're not used to it anymore.
The enterprise market solved that in IT

long ago.
So they don't expect it.
Enterprises don't like high complexity.
They don't want to, you know,

pre-integrate core and radio solutions
and applications on top of those.

They don't have the skills,
they shouldn't need to have the skills.
And then thirdly,

with complicated
complex networks comes long time scales.

So enterprises don't want to wait a year
or a year and a half for a big complex
design to take place.

And then, you know,
another six months to get it operational.
They want faster time to market.

So those three are key areas
that we're aiming to solve.
Kurt what do you think?
Those are all great points

and we really are attacking
every one of those issues sort of head on.
You know, from the

the complexity standpoint,
we work with customers to understand

their use case and really abstract
all the complexity out by

developing templated solutions
that, you know,

include the packet core and RAN

that, you know,
they need on their enterprise.
From the the cost standpoint,
we're driving large ecosystems.

to success for the customer,
